Transcript: Of course, I'd always been associated with movies and playing a certain kind of lady in the movies. I don't like to talk about them as being heavies because they weren't really. They were all characters and interesting. They had an edge to them, some of them, more so than others. I suppose I had that label of being a very strong, dramatic actress. When I had the chance to do Mame, it was just a complete switch of characters. Again, Mame was a character, but what a devil may care, charming, vivacious, effervescent person she was. And certainly, I'd never played that. So that was the thing that really sort of set me up on Broadway, was Mame. And thank goodness it was, because I played her not many times since. In fact, only one other time have I played Mame since today when I'm opening here in Dallas for the third outing with the lady.

I was in one of the departments finding out how it worked and why. And one day, in answer to your question, one day I was really going to throw in the towel. And I said, Joe, I don't know what they want from me, but what kind of a criminal am I because I choose to work so hard? And he said, Jerry, I don't particularly care that you write and direct, because I write and direct. He said, I think you'll find those that are obsessed by it are those that do one thing. And you punctuate the fact that they are single-faceted and they don't like it. He said, and they want you to come over to their side if they can knock you down, then they have one less to be concerned with that. Well, it made a great deal of sense to me. Made me feel better anyhow. He said, the people that do what you do will not attack you for doing what you do. So it's those that either choose not to do what you do or are angry that you do, in fact, do it. It made sense to me. At least it made me feel better. So.

And our formula basically is to mix fantasy with realism. In other words, we'll take a character who's got superhuman power, let's say he can fly through the air, or like Spider-Man, he can climb on walls. So we take these bigger than life characters and we give them very lifelike qualities and problems, and that had never been done in comics before, you see. The heroes had always been just sort of cardboard characters who were always good, virtuous, noble, never worried about money, never had any problems, and they just were.
